Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was reviewing my notes for tonight’s adult education class at the synagogue. It was David, my oldest friend, his voice shaky and urgent—his car had broken down on the highway, miles from town, and he needed me to come get him. I glanced at the clock. The class was in less than an hour. It wasn’t mandatory, but I knew several people were looking forward to it; some had even emailed me questions in advance. As their rabbi, I felt a responsibility to be there, to teach, to show up as a steady presence. But David was alone, scared, and I was the only one he trusted to call. My mind raced with the weight of both roles—my friend needed me, but so did my community. I could feel the tension tightening in my chest, torn between the pull of loyalty and the call of duty, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
